context: It has been convincingly argued that in addition to primary diagnosis, an accepted indication for such a noninvasive test is the follow up to eradication therapy. Indeed, a number of studies have shown it to be equally efficacious in post-treatment diagnosis (21–23). The ability of the urea breath test to accurately diagnose H. pylori status 1 month after eradication therapy confers several advantages, including: the risk of ulcer recurrence before treatment outcome can be determined is low (treatment failures are relatively common), recurrent symptoms can be treated with assurance of the H. pylori status and the shorter wait provides an element of comfort to the physician and patient. A consensus statement recently has advocated the use of urea breath tests as the best noninvasive test for diagnosis of H. pylori infection (24). In this study we have shown that Helikit™ offers excellent clinical sensitivity and specificity for the diagnosis of H. pylori infection. These performance characteristics obviate the need for invasive endoscopy in uncomplicated cases, and prove that a single test is sufficient for primary diagnosis. The judicious application of the urea breath test has the real potential of significant cost savings as endoscopy is an expensive and invasive procedure.
